poem:
### Panto Whispers

In Hackney's glow, the stage alive,  
Dames in sequins, stories strive.  
Rats scuttle, dreams unfold,  
Beneath the lights, silver and gold.  
Laughter like a whisper glides;  
In frocks they twirl, in jest they hide.  
Dick and cat in merry dance,  
Where magic knows its last romance.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Dick Whittington and His Cat review – the rats have no chance in merry panto One day, a panto may come along in which the story is given as much (OK, even half as much) attention as the dame’s frocks, and where the romance between the principal boy and his sweetheart isn’t as flat as the backcloth. Hackney’s Dick Whittington is not that panto. Nope, this is the one wot Clive Rowe is in, the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
